content.title: Septic Shock Management
content.summary: Septic shock is sepsis with circulatory, cellular, and metabolic abnormalities associated with higher mortality. Management follows the Surviving Sepsis Campaign guidelines: rapid identification, early antibiotics, fluid resuscitation, vasopressors to maintain MAP ≥65 mmHg, and source control. The 'hour-1 bundle' emphasizes time-critical interventions.
key_points: Definition: sepsis + vasopressor requirement to maintain MAP ≥65 + lactate >2 despite adequate fluids
Hour-1 bundle: lactate, blood cultures, broad-spectrum antibiotics, 30 mL/kg crystalloid, vasopressors if hypotensive
Norepinephrine is first-line vasopressor; add vasopressin as second agent
Source control (drain abscess, remove infected device) is essential within 6-12 hours
Reassess fluid responsiveness - stop fluids when no longer responsive
Stress-dose steroids for refractory shock (hydrocortisone 200 mg/day)
content.statement: Septic shock management requires immediate implementation of the hour-1 bundle with early antibiotics, fluid resuscitation, norepinephrine for vasopressor support, and source control, with ongoing reassessment to titrate therapy and avoid fluid overload.

explanation.intuition: Sepsis is an overwhelming immune response that damages the body's own vessels, causing them to leak and dilate. Blood pressure drops despite the heart pumping faster. Treatment squeezes the pipes back (vasopressors), refills the tank (fluids), kills the invaders (antibiotics), and removes the source (source control).
explanation.key_insight: Speed matters: each hour delay in antibiotics increases mortality. But more fluids aren't always better - after initial resuscitation, assess fluid responsiveness (passive leg raise, IVC variation) before giving more. Overresuscitation causes harm.
explanation.technical_details: Lactate reflects tissue hypoperfusion and is both diagnostic and prognostic. Target lactate clearance >10% in first 6 hours. qSOFA (≥2 of: RR ≥22, altered mentation, SBP ≤100) identifies patients at risk for poor outcomes. Procalcitonin can guide antibiotic de-escalation.

definitions_glossary.septic_shock: Sepsis with persistent hypotension requiring vasopressors and lactate >2 mmol/L despite adequate resuscitation
definitions_glossary.sepsis: Life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by dysregulated host response to infection
definitions_glossary.qSOFA: Quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment; bedside screening for sepsis risk
definitions_glossary.SOFA_score: Sequential Organ Failure Assessment; quantifies organ dysfunction in sepsis
definitions_glossary.hour_1_bundle: Time-critical interventions to begin within first hour of sepsis recognition
definitions_glossary.norepinephrine: First-line vasopressor for septic shock; alpha-1 agonist with some beta effect
definitions_glossary.vasopressin: Second-line vasopressor in septic shock; non-catecholamine V1 receptor agonist
definitions_glossary.source_control: Interventions to eliminate focus of infection (drainage, debridement, device removal)
definitions_glossary.fluid_responsiveness: Likelihood that cardiac output will increase with additional fluid bolus
definitions_glossary.lactate_clearance: Decrease in lactate over time; indicates improving tissue perfusion
definitions_glossary.stress_dose_steroids: Hydrocortisone 200 mg/day for refractory septic shock
definitions_glossary.procalcitonin: Biomarker of bacterial infection; guides antibiotic duration

pathophysiology.mechanism: Infection → pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) → immune activation → cytokine storm → endothelial dysfunction → capillary leak + vasodilation + microthrombosis → organ dysfunction

hemodynamic_changes.early: Hyperdynamic state - high CO, low SVR, warm shock
hemodynamic_changes.late: Myocardial depression - reduced CO, cold shock
hemodynamic_changes.microcirculation: Shunting and maldistribution despite adequate macrocirculation

sepsis_3_definition.sepsis: Suspected infection + SOFA ≥2 (or increase ≥2 from baseline)
sepsis_3_definition.septic_shock: Sepsis + vasopressor to maintain MAP ≥65 + lactate >2 mmol/L despite adequate fluid resuscitation

differential_diagnosis: Adrenal crisis (may mimic or accompany sepsis)

hour_1_bundle.blood_cultures: Obtain before antibiotics if no significant delay (<45 min)
hour_1_bundle.antibiotics: Broad-spectrum IV within 1 hour; narrow based on cultures
hour_1_bundle.fluids: 30 mL/kg crystalloid for hypotension or lactate ≥4 mmol/L
hour_1_bundle.vasopressors: Norepinephrine if hypotensive during or after fluids to maintain MAP ≥65 mmHg

vasopressor_selection.dobutamine: Add for low CO despite adequate fluid/vasopressor (sepsis-induced cardiomyopathy)

corticosteroids.indication: Refractory shock (still requiring vasopressors despite fluids)
corticosteroids.regimen: Hydrocortisone 50 mg IV q6h or 200 mg/day continuous
corticosteroids.duration: Until shock resolves; taper not necessary

reassessment.when_to_stop_fluids: No longer fluid responsive; signs of fluid overload

definition.@value: The evidence-based approach to managing septic shock including fluid resuscitation, vasopressor therapy, early antibiotics, and source control as outlined in Surviving Sepsis Campaign guidelines

scopeNote.@value: Core critical care competency with time-sensitive interventions

learning_objectives: Apply Sepsis-3 definitions to identify septic shock
Implement the hour-1 bundle for sepsis management
Select appropriate vasopressors for septic shock
Assess fluid responsiveness to guide ongoing resuscitation
Determine appropriate timing and methods for source control
clinical_pearls: Each hour delay in antibiotics increases mortality ~4-7%
30 mL/kg is starting point, not endpoint - reassess fluid responsiveness
Start norepinephrine early - don't wait for massive fluid resuscitation
Lactate clearance predicts outcomes better than absolute lactate value
Source control failures cause most treatment failures
common_misconceptions: More fluids always help - overresuscitation increases mortality
Vasopressors should wait until fluids complete - start early in refractory hypotension
qSOFA replaces SIRS - qSOFA is for prognosis, SIRS criteria still inform diagnosis
